Was drawn to the game finally by all the wonderful stories about the 2.0 version. Last night, I played the demo four times, with four different classes, aaaaaand....

snippet.textDisplay: I cant stand having mini bosses as regular cannon fodder enemies, it makes them even less memorable, and makes the developer come off as lazy, bosses having fodder enemies to make them more “difficult” just creates a sense of confusion without actually being more challenging, showcase the boss and stop compensating by adding bullshit enemies during a BOSS FIGHT, also why does sprinting take up stamina out of combat? It would make the game feel less awkward if they didnt make that objectively stupid decision…..main problem is enemy diversity, far and away, its borderline offensive when you start leveling up your character and enemies that once took two swings now take 4 to 5 swings, its boring, lazy and is the reason this game cant ever rise past a 7.5

snippet.textDisplay:
A little over a minute and a half into the video you said something that broke my reality.  You said you didn't like the Umbral, I believe you use the word "gimmick" which I found astonishing but that's not what broke me, it was the fact that you said, “it looks exactly the same as the regular world, and there were times where you couldn't tell the difference"

 Before I start spitting up brain hemorrhage is from the damage you did, can you please explain how you got confused while in there and thought that the areas looked the same?  I mean yeah they have the same growth all over them that's kind of the point, but none of them actually look identical.  Sure maybe some assets here and there are reused, welcome to game development, but I don't get how you felt that way and I'm thinking you're negative experience with the performance and all the issues of mob density and whatnot at lunch may have skewed your opinion back then.  

Because I and many others feel that the Umbral realm is one of the best/unique things I've ever seen in a Souls like.  

It not only adds more content, enemies, loot and exploration, but it also adds a puzzle mechanic that doesn't feel like a puzzle mechanic most times.  

I expect your apology written in formal quill and deer hide and 100,000 for the damage you did to my brain.

snippet.textDisplay: 20€ for the game + the upgrade pack a week ago. I'm now in Revelation Depths on my main character and have made another 2. Suffice to say I love the game. I found it pretty easy at first but the difficulty ramped up at about the time of the Spurned Progeny and beyond. Getting into the Fief early was also particularly suicidal and showed me that there was more I needed to do. Don't have many complaints outside, like you said, textures in cutscenes not loading properly. Great game all things considered, and anyone can play it for free so long as it's in co-op with someone who has bought the game. And it's only 17€ until Labour Day.

snippet.textDisplay:
Both Lies of P and Lords of the Fallen have good up and down sides for me. But now that we're in 2025, pure combat has to go to First Berserker Khazan for me. I did improve Lies of P (for me personally) with some mods regarding QoL and the parry system. But still... As it stands the games are all great in their own aspect and one MAJOR point for me in regards to Lords is the developers showing such amazing after launch support and updates, while listening to the community.

Happy to have so many ways to play a souls-like nowadays (where is my Nioh 3 Team Ninja god damn you). And I'm interested to see what this team can do in the future.
snippet.textOriginal:
Both Lies of P and Lords of the Fallen have good up and down sides for me. But now that we're in 2025, pure combat has to go to First Berserker Khazan for me. I did improve Lies of P (for me personally) with some mods regarding QoL and the parry system. But still... As it stands the games are all great in their own aspect and one MAJOR point for me in regards to Lords is the developers showing such amazing after launch support and updates, while listening to the community.

Happy to have so many ways to play a souls-like nowadays (where is my Nioh 3 Team Ninja god damn you). And I'm interested to see what this team can do in the future.

snippet.textDisplay:
The "pre upgraded loot" is one of the nicest quality of life features you could have as a game modifier.

At level 100 you find +10 equipment on the ground, you never have to grind for resources and save chunks for boss items or weapons you buy. In Elden Ring, the most fucking annoying thing was grinding the Albunaurics to get souls to actually afford upgrade materials and make the dlc items worth using

snippet.textDisplay: I'm definitely not a hardcore Souls player but I've beaten Elden Ring, DS3, Demon's Souls Remake, and Bloodborne between 2-4 times each, and I just love the way each of those games FEEL. I've tried Lords of the Fallen twice (at launch and at 1.7) and bounced off of it quickly both times. The combat and movement just felt sloppy to me. Floaty and with no weight behind attacks, no sense of impact when you landed or didn't land a blow. In that regard, despite a very cool setting with nice visuals and (imo) very cool music, I just felt disconnected from the game. Despite the bells and whistles it felt older than the current batch of Souls and Souls-like games. Have the movement and combat improvements in 2.0 changed it significantly enough that I will be won over if I was still not digging it at 1.7? The thought of seamless co-op is intriguing but if the game is still mid I won't be able to get anyone to play with me anyway.
snippet.textOriginal: I'm definitely not a hardcore Souls player but I've beaten Elden Ring, DS3, Demon's Souls Remake, and Bloodborne between 2-4 times each, and I just love the way each of those games FEEL. Have the movement and combat improvements in 2.0 changed it significantly enough that I will be won over if I was still not digging it at 1.7? The thought of seamless co-op is intriguing but if the game is still mid I won't be able to get anyone to play with me anyway.

snippet.textDisplay:
I hope in the sequel they do more with the Umbral realm, when I first saw the idea I was thinking of the implementation from The Soul Reaver series, with creative platforming and puzzles that required careful consideration of switching between the material and immaterial realm.

As such I had high hopes for the reboot of the Lords of the Fallen, its too bad they didn't quite nail it this time, but with the updates they've put in, they've earned my good faith and I shall both give this game a try and be more hopeful for the sequel.

snippet.textDisplay:
I played crossplay coop monster hunter wild with my brother since it's release and it barely had any issue because they hammered it during the beta I think (me on pc and my brother on ps5, on the same wifi), the crossplay coop on lords of the fallen 2.0 with my brother though, very often the player that is not the host get bosses that are invisible (only see their weapon swinging), can't move during exploration/small frame stop during fights leading to  not knowing if they killed or got killed or ended up hitting the wind... Mostly get worst at the forsaken fen and the following areas. So yeah, the coop is far from seamless if there are fire in the background/too many enemies... It is great to be able to trade item/gear at least, monster hunter wild don't allow that... 

The enemy/weapon/moveset variety and can't have 3 weapons in each hands can feel annoying too. The enemies that don't respawn and require to be lucky to get their gear(when killing them) can be frustrating too(( 
I think the bosses are really cool personally, I love knights and there are plenty in that game, dark souls 3 was a lot about knights with lot of drip too. The armor knight of adyr is a huge pain to get though (pvp online with random encounter only (pvp with password doesn't give any reward) ), very much felt like grinding a battlepass in a mobile game, erk... They should have given the possibility to unlock it for offline player too... In ds3, the alva armor set was online npc invasion only, I always found that annoying(

In LOTF: having to do quest to unlock special move for weapon is kind of annoying, an added pain in my opinion( Quest in ds3 was a huge pain too, had to follow guide((
The ability to parry with any weapon is very cool, even when two handing one big weapon, the fact that heavy attack just do better poise damage but not more damage feel a bit frustrating... 
And the lamp  and the umbral world is definitely a special thing... Got to switch it anytime you wanna cast a spell or use ranged weapon/throw. But without it, the character we play would be dead... 
So it is not great for the crossplay coop yet, the pvp mostly work very well though, after more than 100 pvp battle, probably only 10% of disconnect that were mostly voluntary from the invaded player I think... I definitely recommend it too if you look for a nice small souls game!

snippet.textDisplay:
played this 2.0 and for me the game seems smoother and somewhat fast paced. Also way lower mobs density (I know this can be changed at the modifier seetings but still think it could be more balanced from the start, as it is set to be). A lot easier too (no way I could first try all those umbral butterflies, bringer of stillness and those proselyte, bulwark, spiked head guys etc that used to give us a pretty hard time). Bosses are a lot easier also.

But really worth it as an RPG souls (also hate all those skill trees thing in other games) and with non-stopping devs.

Nice review!

snippet.textDisplay: I must be the only person who didn't have a problem with the original enemy density. I did a recent playthrough with the now current default enemy density and I feel like there is no challenge to the game whatsoever. Like did no one ever use any ranged options? This is still my favorite soulslike and just me personally I feel like people shit on this game way too hard. Is it perfect? Absolutely not. But I dont understand how people were able to adapt to how Lies of P played but not Lords of the Fallen? For example, people were complaining that they would swing their weapon and fall off the edge. Okay well quit button mashing for a damn second and back away from the edge. Play strategically. Again this is just my opinion.

snippet.textDisplay:
There's always a but.... 🤷🏼‍♂️
I've finished the game yesterday, bought it on release played halfway and then dropped it, because I was disappointed... When I heard of the remake, I gave it another try and I was happy, I loved it. Now that I'm finished I have mixed feelings...
Like he said the build creation is the games biggest strength and probably the main reason why I will keep playing it.
The bosses are Way to easy, even for me.... maybe I was over leveled, but 8 did every late game boss first or second try, especially the fire areas, felt way to overloaded with all the explosions and fire and colors all over the screen, it was just stressful. 
I have to say it, the final boss is a joke... wtf... I beat him second try and I didn't felt rewarded. 
The game is good and I want to love it... but I expected more 😔

snippet.textDisplay: Great review, although i need to point out that to respec you need to purchase an umbral chrysallis at the shrine of the putrid mother, which there is an unlimited supply of. And the currency is probably the easiest to get as you only need to avenge fallen lampbearers or complete the boss gauntlets to get a shit ton of them
